channel.title: Complex Ambiguity on Lewwwk
channel.description: Recent content in Complex Ambiguity on Lewwwk

item.title: Union Square Ventures and a new kind of Venture Capital firm.
item.description:
:::: entry-content {.alignright decoding=“async” height=“162” width=“158”}Yesterday’s, NYTimes{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} article on Union Square Ventures (USV) entitled “A New Kind Of Venture Capital Firm” is an interesting read and I’m glad to see the media beginning to pick up on this.

I’ve been following USV for a whlie now and actually interviewed Brad Burnham in preparation for a session at the Open Everything Retreat on Investing in Open. They seem to have a knack for investing in webtech ventures like Twitter{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} and Wesabe{.zem_slink rel=“homepage”} that have models that can be deeply disruptive to the systems they are taking on and where the question of how they are going to make money from them is far from answered. And now they’re turning more of their attention to conventionally ‘social’ issues including education and the environment.

item.title: The dynamics of the frontier: complex ambiguity
item.description:
::: entry-content The frontiers of venturing are the places where conventional venturing and planning approaches become least effective. It is the effective limit of conventional approaches to venturing that define the edge of the frontier with the deepest depths of the frontier being the pre-concept stage of a systemically focused venture.
{decoding=“async” style=“margin: 10px 10px 0pt 0pt; float: left; width: 286px; height: 265px;”}
Conventional approaches loose effectiveness the earlier a venture is in the development phase because of increasing ambiguity.  The less that is known the harder it is to do linear modeling and planning.  Choices made continually reduce ambiguity as the venture moves along the development and into the realm where conventional planning approaches can be effectively used.
